title: A Theory of Craft: Function and Aesthetic Expression
desc: An art historian develops a comprehensive theory of the craft process and the studio craft disciplines.

title: Abstracting Craft: The Practiced Digital Hand
desc: Suggests that designing on the computer is an instance of hand craft, with nods to process.

title: Aesthetics of the Everyday
desc: An anthology on the topic of environmental aesthetics and the efforts that opened the field of aesthetics beyond the fine arts during the latter half of twentieth century.

title: Against Interpretation
section: In : Against Interpretation and Other Essays, 96-104
source: Against Interpretation and Other Essays : Penguin Classics
desc: A critical look at artistic criticism and an argument for resisting predetermined interpretations of visual works based on their content and meaning.

title: Akademie X: Lessons in Art + Life
desc: 36 legendary art teachers—artists and critics themselves—on the ideal curriculum for an aspiring artist.

title: Art and Its Objects
desc: Contains a classic reflection on expression, representation, style, the significance of the artist's intention.

title: Art as Experience
desc: Makes a case for seeing art as an intellectual achievement of human history and living proof of our experiences.

title: Art as Performance
desc: Contains a valuable new perspective on the issue of material and medium.

title: Art in the Making: Artists and Their Materials from the Studio to Crowdsourcing
desc: A look at individual processes of making through a collection of 9 crafts: Painting, Woodworking, Building, Performing, Tooling Up, Cashing In, Fabricating, Digitizing, and Crowdsourcing

title: Art School: Propositions for the 21st Century
desc: Includes discussion of “deskilling,” a persistent effort to eliminate the need forartisanal competence.

title: Artistry: The Work of Artists.
desc: A study of the craft process by a philosopher who refreshingly uses singing as a case study.

title: As Radical, As Mother, as Salad, as Shelter: What Should Art Institutions Do Now?,
desc: A series of essays chronicling the change in the positioning of art institutions vis-a-vis political activism.

title: Batch: Craft, Design and Product
desc: Essays on the designer-maker trend in the design profession.

title: Blurred Boundaries? Rethinking the Concept of Craft and its Relation to Art and Design
desc: Argues that the boundary between art and craft conceived as a set of disciplines defined by materials and techniques has not become blurred, it has all but disappeared.

title: By Hand: The Use of Craft in Contemporary Art.
desc: Features the work of thirty-two artists whose innovative and unexpected uses of handicraft techniques.

title: Choosing Craft: The Artist’s Viewpoint
desc: A history and practice of American craft through the words of influential artists whose lives, work, and ideas have shaped the field.

title: Craft
desc: A secret history of craft told through lost and overlooked texts that illuminate our understanding of current art practice.

title: Crafting Modernism: Midcentury American Art and Design
desc: On the origins of the studio craft movement and its convergence with the fine arts and design.

title: Crafts, Perception, and the Possibilities of the Body
desc: On craft as grounded in “enactive” psychological mechanisms with functional purposes grounded in our everyday bodily habits.

title: Critique of the Power of Judgment
desc: On the aesthetic and teleological questions, and our formations of subjectivity.

title: Defending Everyday Aesthetics and the Concept of 'Pretty'
section: In : Contemporary Aesthetics (Journal Archive): Vol. 10 , Article 8.
desc: A close analysis of the concept of pretty to suggest the ways it ignores the importance of aesthetic value in the parts of our lives not devoted to art.

title: Denise Gonzales Crisp: The decorational
desc: On the role of the decorative in practices of graphic design, specifically as they pertain to typography

title: Design and Crime, and Other Diatribes
desc: On design excess in the modern spectacle that is the marketing of culture and the branding of identity.

title: Design as Art
desc: An illustrated journey into the artistic possibilities of modern design, guided by the creative mind of the Italian artist and designer Bruno Munari.

title: Embodied Meanings: Critical Essays & Aesthetic Meditations
desc: Features two important essays on craft in art, one a review of Martin Puryear, the other on function in fine art.

title: Everyday Aesthetics
desc: On cultivating an awareness of everyday aesthetic experiences and using this to exert powerful influence on the state.

title: Extra/Ordinary: Craft and Contemporary Art
desc: An wide-ranging introduction to the “craft culture” referenced and celebrated by artists promoting new ways of thinking about the role of craft in contemporary art.

title: Functional Beauty
desc: An in-depth philosophical study of the relationship between function and aesthetic value, breaking with the philosophical tradition of seeing the two as separate.

title: Functionalism Today
section: In : The Craft Reader. Ed. Glenn Adamson. Oxford: Berg, 2011. 395–403.
desc: On the self-contradictions endemic to to artistic production constrained by social conditions.

title: Hand + Made: The Performative Impulse in Art and Craft
desc: Featuring artists working to broaden the context and function of the handmade object, blurring the distinctions between performance and sculpture.

title: Handmade Nation: The Rise of DIY, Art, Craft and Design
desc: A close look at the contemporary craft movement’s embrace of emerging makers working in traditional and nontraditional media

title: Journal of Modern Craft
desc: The first peer-reviewed academic journal to provide an interdisciplinary and international forum in its subject area.

title: Listening to Clay: Conversations with Contemporary Japanese Ceramic Artists
desc: A look at the ingenuity and trailblazing that has shaped contemporary art in Japan and around the world, guided by conversation with contemporary artists ranging in age from sixty-two to ninety-two.

title: Loving Attention: An Outburst of Craft in Contemporary Art
section: In : Extra/Ordinary, Ed. Maria Elena Buszek, 222–42.
desc: A window into demonstrations of craft beginning to play leading roles in the significance of the handmade object within contemporary art practice.

title: Machine in the Studio: Constructing the Postwar American Artist
desc: A fresh look at the art world of the 1960s.

title: Macrame of Resistance
desc: On the role of craft in the design and the need to move beyond its purely conceptual and technical activations.

title: Make a Chair from a Tree
desc: A instructional book that helped ignite a green woodworking movement in the United States and positioned wordworkers to use trees sustainably.

title: Makers: A History of American Studio Craft
desc: The first comprehensive history of studio craft in the United States.

title: Making and Being: Embodiment, Collaboration, and Circulation in the Visual Arts, A Workbook
desc: A hands-on guide containing activities, worksheets, and assignments, offering a framework for teaching art that emphasizes contemplation, collaboration, and political economy.

title: Making Is Connecting: The Social Meaning of Creativity: From DIY and Knitting to YouTube and Web 2.0.
desc: Highlighting the ways that making things allows people to engage thoughtfully  with the world around them.

title: Neocraft: Modernity and the Crafts
source: The Press of the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design
desc: Challenges the marginal role that craft has played in Modernist discourse with a wide selection of scholarship on the subject.

firstname: M. Anna and Paula Owen, ed.
title: Objects and Meaning: New Perspectives on Art and Craft
desc: Questions how various academic and cultural institutions assign meaning to artist-made objects in postmodern North America.

title: Philosophizing with a Hammer: Gary Knox Bennett and Contemporary Art
section: In : Made in Oakland: The Furniture of Gary Knox Bennett, edited by Ursula Ilse-Neuman, pp. 3–13.
source: Made in Oakland : American Craft Museum
desc: A close look at Danto’s position on craft and its relation to art.

title: Redesigning the World: William Morris, the 1880s and the Arts and Crafts Movement
desc: On William Morris and his definitive influence on the craft revolution of the late 1800s.

title: String, Felt, Thread: The Hierarchy of Art and Craft in American Art
desc: A history of the struggle for the fiber arts to gain recognition from the cultural sector as an art.

title: Tacit Knowledge, Rule-Following and Learning
section: In : Artificial Intelligence, Culture and Language: On Education and Work, edited by Bo Göranzon and Magnus Florin, pp. 45–55.
source: Artificial Intelligence, Culture and Language : Springer-Verlag
desc: A critique of both critics and defenders of this concept of “tacit knowledge” and its importance in new design technologies.

title: TEXTile Manifestoes
desc: An interdisciplinary anthology that assembles and interweaves questions related to textile art, fashion and textuality into broader socio-politcal contexts

title: The Art Form That Dares Not Speak Its Name
desc: On making “craft” a dirty word and the question that bedevils practitioners and museum insiders.

title: The Art Instinct: Beauty, Pleasure, and Human Evolution
desc: Offers early insight into both the nature of art and the workings of the human mind, through the lens of evolutionary science.

title: The Art of Not Making: The New Artist/Artisan Relationship
desc: A review of 115 contemporary artists, and the ways they collaborate with craftspeople to realize their work.

title: The Art of the Maker: Skill and Its Meaning in Art, Craft and Design
desc: On process and content as interdependent and mutually enriching facets of a communal culture of artistic discovery.

title: The Arts & Crafts Movement in Europe & America
The Arts and Crafts Movement in America
desc: A bief history of the Arts and Crafts Movement in North America.

title: The Arts and The Defintion of the Human
desc: Suggests that our creation and perception of art will always be mitigated by our historical and cultural contexts.

title: The Beauty of Everyday Things
desc: A hugely influential exposition of the Japanese philosopher's view of folkcrafts, setting out the hallmarks of Japanese design as we know it today.

title: The Black Craftsman Situation':  A Critical Conversation about Race and Craft
section: In : The New Politics of the Handmade: Craft, Art & Design, 250-266
source: The New Politics of the Handmade : Bloomsbury
desc: A roundtable conversation with Sonya Clark, Wesley Clark, Bibiana Obler, Mary Savig, Joyce Scott, and Namita Gupta Wiggers.

title: The Craft Reader
desc: A range of both classic and contemporary texts on the different traditions of craft, covering the period from the Industrial Revolution to today,

title: The Crafts in Britain in the 20th Century
The Craftsman
desc: An original perspective on craftsmanship and its close connections to work and ethical values and how one might engage the multiple dimsions of skill.

title: The Culture of Craft: Status and Future.
The Decriminalization of Ornament
The Fate of Craft
section: In : NeoCraft: Craft and Modernity, edited by Sandra Alfoldy, pp. 33–46.
source: Press of the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design

title: The Ideology of the Aesthetic
section: In : Poetics Today, Vol. 9, No. 2, The Rhetoric of Interpretation and the Interpretation of Rhetoric

title: The Intangibles of Form: Skill and Deskilling in Art after the Readymade. L
The Invention of Art: A Cultural History
The Invention of Craft
desc: A theoretical discussion of skilled work, reaching backwards in time and across numerous disciplines to suggest its relationship to invention.

title: The Madonna of the Future: Essays in a Pluralistic Art World
The Nature and Art of Workmanship
desc: An exploration of the meaning of skill and its relationship to design and manufacturing, which proposes a new theory of making based on the concepts of 'workmanship of risk' and 'workmanship of certainty.'

title: The Nature of Everyday Aesthetics
section: In : The Aesthetics of Everyday Life, edited by Andrew Light and Jonathan M. Smith, pp. 3–23.
source: The Aesthetics of Everyday Life : Columbia University Press

title: The New Politics of the Handmade: Craft, Art & Design
desc: Twenty-three voices rethinking the handmade in the contecxt of a dramatically shifting global economy inseparable from production and consumption.

title: The Persistence of Craft: The Applied Arts Today
desc: A look at studio arts from woodworking, ceramics and glass to jewellery, metalworking and textiles, and the factors that have shaped their development.

title: The Practice of Everyday Life
desc: On the fundamental practices of a "fine art of dwelling," in which places are organized in a network of history and relationship.

title: The Tacit Dimension
desc: Argues that tacit knowledge—tradition, inherited practices, implied values, and prejudgments—is a crucial part of scientific knowledge.

title: The Theory of Decorative Art: An Anthology of European & American Writings, 1750–1940.
desc: An anthology of European and American writings on

title: Thinking through Craft
desc: Reviews the status of "workmanship" in the contempoary arts and nakes a case for defining craft in a more nuanced fashion.

title: What is Art For?
desc: On art-making as an innately human behavior—as intrinsic to the species as speech and toolmaking.

title: Wild Things: The Material Culture of Everyday Life
desc: Bridging design theory and anthropology to offer a new and challenging way of understanding the changing meanings of contemporary human-object relations.

title: Work Ethic
desc: A look at the avant-garde interventions in art of 1960s linking a "dematerialization" of the object with the free play of concepts, produced in tandem with an exhibition of the same name.

title: Working: People Talk Abut What They Do All Day and How They Feel About What They Do
desc: An investigation, through conversational dialogue, of the meaning of work for different people under different circumstances,

title: That Crafty Feeling
section: In : The Believer Magazine, Issue Fifty-Four
desc: A lecture given to student of the Columbia University's Creative Writing Program on the subject of craft
